content.description: To the left of the black streak. Finding holds is challenging on the lighter-colored rock.

Pulls through 3 bolts of semi-chossy rock to a small ledge system. Hard pulls on crimps and really slopy slopers to a left leaning dihedral. Shake here and then the climb finishes in a crack requiring technique. Consensus needed on grade.

This route was bolted by B. Boyle.
content.location: To the left of Electron blue (aka Bizzler)

content.description: Starts with a steep roof and a nice juggy headwall with some business at the top.
content.protection: Bolts.  I would stick clip at least the first bolt on every route at this crag because its a bit chossy at the base.
content.location:
Starts right of the

Uncle Bill

. This is the right most route at the upper tier (with chalk on it). The (incorrect) name "Drizzler" and grade are at the base.

content.description: Start under small roof and pull over 2nd bolt using small holds and side pulls. Steep overhanging jugs leads to a technical crimpy crux to the chains.
content.location:
Located on the second wall of Damascus. At the base of the wall there are three (incorrect) route names written in chalk. The fizzler12a, the chizzler12b, and the drizzler12c.

Uncle Bill

(labeled "The Chizzler", .12b) and is in the middle of the three routes.

content.description: Rightmost route on this section of the wall.  Popular cobbles and pockets.  Still cleaning up, but well worth it.
content.protection: 8 QD's , plus chain anchor and a helmet for your belayer.

content.description: The start is similar to most of the routes in this sector and it is sandy and loose.  The crux comes as you approach the 4th bolt.  From here, hold on and make big moves to reach the jugs.   A little harder than Looking for Yesterday.
content.location: Located on the left sector of the Damascus Wall.   Shares a start with Looking for Yesterday.

content.description: Short but pumpy.
content.location: Just up and around the corner.  The leftmost route on this section of the wall.

content.description: Just left of, and an even dirtier start than Grunt.  Climbs the left side of the black water streak.
content.protection: 8-10 QD's + anchors.  Goggles and a helmet.

content.description: Difficult start leads to better holds above.  Stick clip anyone?
Starts left of and outside the steeper part of the wall.  More technical face climbing.

Climb up and try not to get suckered out left.   Make a kind of tricky clip before gaining a great rest stance.   Head up and left and prepare for the thin crux.   Once you pull the crux, pass the chains of Shunt Mouth, bust an undercling move and hold on until the finish.
content.location: This route shares the start of Shunt Mouth, 12a and heads right.

content.description: Continuous for the grade.
Dirty, bouldery start leads out of the overhang left of 50 Something (Tree Route).  Follows the black water streak.
content.protection: 8-10 QD's + anchors.  Goggles and a helmet.

content.description: Technical and sequential crux pulling the first roof, followed by sustained climbing to a potential red point crux a body length beneath the chains.  As of summer 2012 the first third of the route is still pretty fresh, but rock quality improves above that. This will be an excellent route with a few hundred more ascents.
content.location:
This route is on the left side of the uppermost wall in the

Damascus

area. It is just right of the 12d

Welcome Back Cobble

and just left of the 12a,

Dr. Goodkind

.

content.description:
Starts under roof, pull on a mix of jugs and slopers to the top. This is not often climbed, so it is recommended to climb cautiously and stick clip the first bolt.

AKA- Sizzler
content.location: Far right climb on the right wall.

content.description: Crux comes right off the ground. Pull a small roof at 2nd bolt and continue through on large holds. Another small crux pulling the bulge up top to easier climbing to the chains.
content.location:
Located on the second wall of Damascus. At the base of the wall there are three incorrect route names written in chalk. The fizzler 12a, the chizzler 12b, and the drizzler 12c.

Dr. Goodkind

(incorrectly labeled "The Fizzler") is labeled 12a and is the leftmost of the three routes

content.description: Choss and more choss. Climb with care.
content.location: This climb is located about 1/2 way down the hill approaching the right hand side of the Damuscus wall.

content.description: This route has really cleaned up.   The crux comes just before the halfway point where the holds get thin and you have a choice to make a big throw to a good hold or do a few more moves to the right before getting to the good hold.   The climbing stays on you for a bit and gives a redpoint crux in the upper sandstone section.
content.location: Just to the left of Shunt Mouth.

content.description: This route has quite a variety of climbing and tends to be fairly bouldery.   Climb through the sandy start to reach a pair of finger pockets above the first scoop on Scoops, 12c.   From here, boulder through some small holds and gain a stance.   Then it's a series of finger pockets to the best rest on the route.   The rest of the climb is just trying to manage the pump to the finish through the black streak.
content.location: Just to the left of Brother Clucker, 12b

content.description: Follows the black streak. OK climbing, but I would think one section is a little heady for a 5.11- climber.
content.location: On the hillside, left of Chossaholic

content.description: What a cool route!  The most striking line on this section of cliff and most people's favorite.   Climb up and left connecting the 3 scoops in the rock.   Very bouldery.   A kneebar helps to shake off some pump at the 3rd scoop before heading into the crux.   From there, it's just staying cool and shaking when you can in the black streak to the top.
content.location: Just to the left of Baintree, 12c.

content.description: This route would be so much better if that darn tree wasn't there.   Start in the alcove just to the left of Scoops.   The rock is steep and sandy for the first 3 bolts and the moves are very bouldery.   After gaining a stance above the large pod, the angle lessens and the climbing slowly becomes more technical.   As you proceed higher, you'll begin to go directly behind the tree.   Just before the last bolt, it gets very thin.   As much as you want to climb away from the tree, the best holds pull you back to being behind it.   After the last bolt, it's big positive holds to the finish but a fall here probably puts you in the tree.
content.location: Just to the left of Scoops (51)
